brief_summary.textblock:
Untreated ankle sprains often remain symptomatic and may end in chronic instability. The aim
      of our study is to quantify the stabilizing effect of different devices. Through the
      combined use of the 3D motion analysis and the surface electromyography, the influence of
      the devices with respect to a mechanical effect and to an influence on the neuromuscular
      control are examined. The tests will simulate situations with a higher risk of injury. In
      the experimental set-up, an element of surprise will be integrated in order to analyze any
      muscular compensation mechanisms.

clinical_study.brief_title: Neuromuscular Control of the Ankle With External Support

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  chronic ankle instability

          -  "giving way"

          -  repeated ankle sprains

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  other injuries of the lower extremities

          -  surgery on the lower extremities

facility.name: Department of Orthopedics, Trauma Surgery and Spinal Cord Injury, Heidelberg University Hospital

overall_official.affiliation: Dep. of Orthopedics, Trauma Surgery and Spinal Cord Injury

primary_outcome.measure: Change in elektromyographic signal in peroneus longus muscle (surface EMG)
primary_outcome.time_frame: baseline (=before) and immediately after applying the device

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Prevention
